raw_text:
Doors open at biggest gadget fair
 
 Thousands of technology lovers and industry experts have gathered in Las Vegas for the annual Consumer Electronics Show (CES).
 
 The fair showcases the latest technologies and gadgets that will hit the shops in the next year. About 50,000 new products will be unveiled as the show unfolds. Microsoft chief Bill Gates is to make a pre-show keynote speech on Wednesday when he is expected to announce details of the next generation Xbox.
 
 The thrust of this year's show will be on technologies which put people in charge of multimedia content so they can store, listen to, and watch what they want on devices any time, anywhere. About 120,000 people are expected to attend the trade show which stretches over more than 1.5 million square feet. Highlights will include the latest trends in digital imaging, storage technologies, thinner flat screen and high-definition TVs, wireless and portable technologies, gaming, and broadband technologies. The show also includes several speeches from key technology companies such as Intel, Microsoft, and Hewlett Packard among others. "The story this year remains all about digital and how that is completely transforming and revolutionising products and the way people interact with them," Jeff Joseph, from the Consumer Electronics Association (CEA) told the BBC News website. "It is about personalisation - taking your MP3 player and creating your own playlist, taking your digital video recorder and watch what you want to watch when - you are no longer at the whim of the broadcasters."
 
 Consumer electronics and gadgets had a phenomenal year in 2004, according to figures released by CES organisers, the CEA, on Tuesday. The gadget explosion signalled the strongest growth yet in the US in 2004. Shipments of consumer electronics rose by almost 11% between 2003 and 2004. That trend is predicted to continue, according to CEA analysts, with wholesale shipments of consumer technologies expected to grow by 11% again in 2005. The fastest-growing technologies in 2004 included blank DVD media, Liquid Crystal Display (LCD) TVs, digital video recorders (DVRs), and portable music players. "This year we will really begin to see that come to life in what we call place shifting - so if you have your PVR [personal video recorder] in your living room, you can move that content around the house. "Some exhibitors will be showcasing how you can take that content anywhere," said Mr Joseph. He said the products which will be making waves in the next year will be about the "democratisation" of content - devices and technologies that will give people the freedom to do more with music, video, and images. There will also be more focus on the design of technologies, following the lead that Apple's iPod made, with ease of use and good looks which appeal to a wider range of people a key concern.
 
 The CEA predicted that there would be several key technology trends to watch in the coming year. Gaming would continue to thrive, especially on mobile devices, and would reach out to more diverse gamers such as women. Games consoles sales have been declining, but the launch of next generation consoles, such as Microsoft's Xbox and PlayStation, could buoy up sales. Although it has been widely predicted that Mr Gates would be showcasing the new Xbox, some media reports have cast doubt on what he would be talking about in the keynote. Some have suggested the announcement may take place at the Games Developers Conference in the summer instead. With more than 52% of US homes expected to have home networks, the CEA suggested hard drive boxes - or media servers - capable of storing thousands of images, video and audio files to be accessed through other devices around the home, will be more commonplace. Portable devices that combine mobile telephony, digital music and video players, will also be more popular in 2005. Their popularity will be driven by more multimedia content and services which will let people watch and listen to films, TV, and audio wherever they are. This means more storage technologies will be in demand, such as external hard drives, and flash memory like SD cards. CES runs officially from 6 to 9 January.
llama3.2:1b: Thousands of technology enthusiasts gathered at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas for about 50,000 new products unveiled.
The show focuses on technologies that give people control over multimedia content, allowing them to store, listen to, and watch what they want on devices anywhere.
Key speakers include Microsoft chief Bill Gates, Intel, and Hewlett Packard, who will discuss their latest trends in digital imaging, storage technologies, gaming, and broadband.
CES organizers predict a 11% growth in wholesale shipments of consumer electronics in 2005, with the fastest-growing technologies including blank DVD media, LCD TVs, DVRs, and portable music players.
llama3.2:3b: Thousands of technology lovers have gathered in Las Vegas for the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) to showcase the latest gadgets and technologies.
Microsoft's Bill Gates is expected to announce details of the next generation Xbox during his keynote speech.
This year's show focuses on technologies that put people in charge of multimedia content, including digital imaging, storage, gaming, and broadband technologies.
CES organizers predict 11% growth in consumer electronics shipments for 2005, with a focus on "democratisation" of content and design.
gemma2:2b: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is showcasing the latest technology advancements in Las Vegas.
Over 120,000 attendees are expected, with key figures including Microsoft's Bill Gates, who is rumored to announce the next-generation Xbox at CES.
Highlights include advancements in digital imaging, storage technologies, and portable devices like TVs, music players, and smartphones.
CES organizers predict strong growth for consumer electronics in 2005 due to the expanding use of home networks and personal multimedia experiences.
Portable devices will become increasingly popular as they offer more content consumption options, leading to greater demand for storage solutions.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Gadget enthusiasts gathered for the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) this year, which covers a wide range of technology products.
Over 50, 000 new products will be unveiled at CES.
Microsoft's Bill Gates is expected to make a pre-show keynote speech on Wednesday.
Highlights include digital imaging and storage technologies, thinner flat screens and high-definition TVs, wireless and portable technologies, gaming and broadband technologies.
The show includes speeches from key technology companies like Intel, Microsoft, and Hewlett Packard.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Thousands of technology enthusiasts gather at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) for its annual showcase of new gadgets expected to hit stores next year.
Microsoft's Bill Gates will deliver a keynote on Wednesday about the Xbox console's future, with digital technologies transforming content consumption and personalization becoming key themes.
More than 120,000 attendees expect to see innovations in digital imaging, storage, thin screens, high-definition TVs, wireless and portable devices, gaming, broadband, and more.

The event features speeches from tech giants like Intel, Microsoft, and Hewlett Packard, with a focus on the "democratisation" of content, including easy-to-use design features appealing to wider demographics.

Sales projections indicate continued growth in consumer electronics, especially blank DVD media, LCD TVs, digital video recorders, and portable music players, with gaming consoles poised for comeback thanks to new console releases from Microsoft and Sony.

The CEA predicts the following trends: mobile game expansion, diverse gamers targeting women, home networking compatibility, multimedia storage devices, and seamless integration of mobile telephony, digital music, and video players.
qwen2.5:3b: Dozens of thousands gather for the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas, showcasing new tech gadgets set to hit stores next year.
Key topics include personal multimedia content control, digital imaging, storage, flat screen TVs, wireless and portable technologies, gaming, and broadband.
Technologies emphasizing user freedom and design appeal are expected to gain traction.
Gaming is predicted to continue thriving, particularly on mobile devices.
CES forecasts growth in home network hard drive boxes and popularizing multimedia-enabled portable devices like smartphones integrating music/video players.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary is:

* Doors open at biggest gadget fair
* Thousands of technology lovers and industry experts have gathered in Las Vegas for the annual Consumer Electronics Show (CES).
* The show showcases the latest technologies and gadgets that will hit the shops in the next year.
* About 50,000 new products will be unveiled as the show unfolds.
* Microsoft chief Bill Gates is to make a pre-show keynote speech on Wednesday when he is expected to announce details of the next generation Xbox.
* The thrust of this year's show will be on technologies which put people in charge of multimedia content so they can store, listen to, and watch what they want on devices any time, anywhere.
* About 120,000 people are expected to attend the trade show which stretches over more than 1.5 million square feet.

* Highlights will include the latest trends in digital imaging, storage technologies, thinner flat screen and high-definition TVs, wireless and portable technologies, gaming, and broadband technologies.
* The story this year remains all about digital and how that is completely transforming products and the way people interact with them.

It is about personalisation - taking your MP3 player and creating your own playlist, taking your digital video recorder and watch what you want to watch when - you are no longer at the whim of the broadcasters.
* It is predicted that there will be several key technology trends to watch in the coming year.
Gaming would continue to thrive, especially on mobile devices, and would reach out to more diverse gamers such as women.
Games consoles sales have been declining, but the launch of next generation consoles, such as Microsoft's Xbox and PlayStation, could buoy up sales.
* Although it has been widely predicted that Mr Gates would be showcasing the new Xbox, some media reports have cast doubt on what he would be talking about in the keynote.
Some have suggested the announcement may take place at the Games Developers Conference (GDC) instead of CES.

With more than 52% of US homes expected to have home networks, the CEA suggested hard drive boxes - or media servers - capable of storing thousands of images, video and audio files to be accessed through other devices around the home, will be more commonplace in 2005.
* CES runs officially from 6 to 9 January.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is expected to see a vibrant lineup of new technologies across 15 million square feet in Las Vegas this year.
Microsoft's next-generation Xbox will be highlighted, along with other industry leaders.
The event focuses on democratizing content access, allowing users to control and personalize multimedia content anytime and anywhere.
Key trends include digital imaging, storage solutions, wireless devices, gaming, and broadband connectivity.
With growing consumer electronics sales (over 11% year-over-year in 2004), the show continues to drive innovation.
The CEA emphasized personalization through music playlists, video capture, and personalizing home networks.
Microsoft's Xbox is expected to be a major highlight, while gaming trends are expanding, especially on mobile devices.
tinyllama:1.1b: The CES (Consumer Electronics Show) annual trade show has attracted over one million people, with the biggest gadget fair in history.

The focus of this year's show is technologies that put people in charge of multimedia content, such as digital imaging, storage technologies, thin-thin flat screen and high-definition TVs, wireless and portable technologies, gamers, and broadband technologies.
Some trennds to watch in the next year include demonstrating more freedom of use in devices, easy-to-use designs, and mobile devices' gaming capabilities.
The Xbox is expected to be showcased at a keynote, but more emphasis will be placed on multimedia content and services like external hard drives and flash memory storage.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES), held annually in Las Vegas, will feature a host of exciting technologies this year, including the latest gadgets and innovations that will shape people's lives over the coming year.

This gathering of industry experts, tech lovers, and technology enthusiasts is expected to attract nearly 50,000 attendees, who will have the chance to witness firsthand these groundbreaking products and technologies that are set to revolutionize our lives.
Some of the key trends being discussed include the democratization of content on various devices, the gamification of gaming experiences, and the introduction of new types of storage solutions.

Additionally, this year's show will explore the future of digital and wireless technology, with a particular focus on multimedia content and services that can be stored, listened to, and watched anywhere at any time.
phi:2.7b: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas is the biggest gadget fair where thousands of technology lovers and industry experts gather.
About 50,000 new products are unveiled every year at this show.
This year's focus is on technologies that put people in charge of multimedia content such as video recording, gaming, and storage.
The CES also features speeches from key technology companies like Intel, Microsoft, and Hewlett Packard.
Sales of consumer electronics have been growing rapidly, with projected growth of 11% in the coming year.
Gaming is one area expected to thrive, especially on mobile devices, while portable devices that combine telephony, digital music, and video players are also predicted to be popular.
More storage technologies will be in demand as people store more multimedia content around their homes.
orca-mini:3b: Las Vegas is hosting the annual Consumer Electronics Show (CES) which showcases the latest technologies and gadgets that will hit the shops in the next year.
Bill Gates, the CEO of Microsoft, is expected to give a keynote speech on Wednesday.
The thrust of this year's show is on personalization and taking control of multimedia content.
Attendees include 120,000 people from various industries such as technology, retail, and media.
The fastest-growing technologies in 2004 included blank DVD media, Liquid Crystal Display (LCD) TVs, digital video recorders (DVRs), and portable music players.
Gaming will continue to thrive, especially on mobile devices, and will reach out to more diverse gamers such as women.
The launch of next generation consoles, such as Microsoft's Xbox and PlayStation, could buoy up sales.

With 52% of US homes expected to have home networks, the CEA suggested hard drive boxes - or media servers - capable of storing thousands of images, video and audio files to be accessed through other devices around the home will become more commonplace.
Portable devices that combine mobile telephony, digital music, and video players will also be more popular in 2005.
The availability of storage technologies such as external hard drives and flash memory like SD cards will increase.
hermes3:3b: CES technology fair in Las Vegas with focus on multimedia personalisation, growing consumer electronics shipments, key trends including gaming growth, home networks, portable devices & storage technologies.

The event focused on technologies allowing users to control multimedia content and personalize their experiences.
Key trends included digital imaging, storage technologies, thinner flat screens, high-definition TVs, wireless and portable devices, gaming, and broadband innovations.
CES saw a significant growth in consumer electronics shipments between 2003 and 2004, with predictions of another 11% increase for 2005.
The fair showcased products that would "democratize" content and focus on design as a crucial element appealing to a wider audience.

Microsoft’s Bill Gates is expected to announce details of the next-generation Xbox.

stablelm2:1.6b: The annual Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas showcases the latest technology products that will hit stores in the next year.
Approximately 10,0 HUNDRED attendees are expected for an extensive trade show that covers over 1.5 million square feet.
The main focus is on technologies that empower individuals to control multimedia content and store their preferred media on devices anywhere at any time.
About 90% of this year's products will be unveiled during the event, which includes several speeches from key technology companies like Intel, Microsoft, Hewlett Packard, among others.
This year marks the "democratisation" of content with devices and technologies that empower people to do more with music, video, and images.

The trends predicted for 2014 include gaming on mobile devices, more focus on the design of technology following Apple's iPod's lead, and an increase in hard drive boxes or media servers capable of storing thousands of images, videos, and audio files.
Portable devices combining telephony, digital music, and video players will also be more popular as they continue to grow in demand due to increased multimedia content and services.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The annual Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas brings together thousands of technology enthusiasts and industry leaders.
This year's event showcases approximately 50,000 new products, focusing on technologies that empower consumers to manage their multimedia content independently, anytime, anywhere.
Highlights include digital imaging advancements, storage solutions, thinner TVs, wireless and portable devices, gaming, and broadband technologies.
Keynote speaker Bill Gates is expected to announce the next-generation Xbox during his pre-show speech on Wednesday.
The event underscores a growing trend in digital personalization, enabling users to curate their content without relying on broadcasters.

In 2004, consumer electronics saw an 11% increase in shipments, and CEA analysts predict a continuation of this growth in 2005, with the fastest-growing categories being blank DVD media, LCD TVs, digital video recorders (DVRs), and portable music players.
CES will exhibit products that democratize content access through "place shifting" and home networks, allowing users to share multimedia files across devices.
Growth of hard drive boxes (media servers) for storing and sharing media files within households.
Increased popularity of portable devices combining mobile telephony, digital music, and video players.
Expansion of multimedia content and services for on-the-go consumption.
Greater demand for storage technologies like external hard drives and flash memory (SD cards).
Emergence of gaming as a diverse market, attracting women gamers.
Continued interest in mobile gaming despite declining console sales due to next-generation console launches like Microsoft's Xbox.
CES takes place from January 6 to 9, 2005.
